title-group.article-title: Molecular determination of genotoxic effects of cobalt and nickel on maize (Zea mays L.) by RAPD and protein analyses

contrib-group.aff: Department of Biology, Atatürk University, Erzurum, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: Guleray Agar, Department of Biology, Atatürk University, Erzurum 25240, Turkey. Email: gagar@atauni.edu.tr

abstract.p: Assessment of DNA damages stemming from toxic chemicals is an important issue in terms of genotoxicology. In this study, maize (Zea mays L.) seedlings were used for screening the genotoxic effects of cobalt (Co) and nickel (Ni) treatments at various concentrations (5 mM, 10 mM, 20 mM and 40 mM). For this purpose, randomly amplified polymorphic DNA (RAPD) technique was applied to genomic DNA extracted from metal-exposed and unexposed plant materials. Besides, changes in total protein contents were screened by sodium dodecyl sulfate–polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE) analysis. For RAPD analysis, 16 RAPD primers were found to produce unique polymorphic band profiles on different concentrations of Co-/Ni-treated maize seedlings. Increased polymorphism resulting from the appearance of new bands or disappearance of normal bands was observed with increasing concentration of Co and Ni treatments. Genomic template stability, a qualitative measurement of changes in RAPD patterns of genomic DNA, decreased with increasing metal concentration. In SDS-PAGE analysis, it was observed that the total soluble protein content decreased by Co treatment, while it increased by Ni treatment. The results obtained from this study revealed that RAPD profiles and total soluble protein levels can be applied to detect genotoxicity, and these analyses can offer useful biomarker assays for the evaluation of genotoxic effects on Co- and Ni-polluted plants.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The increase in the use of heavy metals resulted in the contamination of the environment. Heavy metals pose serious problems for the environment and human health because they are the pollutants that cannot be degraded to nontoxic forms. Problems caused by the heavy metals could be overcome by preventing them from causing contamination or removing them from the environment. Metal extraction and fabrication, surface plating and painting, battery production, and so on, are major anthropogenic sources of heavy metal release into the environment (Jabeen et al., 2009; Mejare and Bülow, 2001; Rengaraj et al., 2002).

Nickel (Ni) and cobalt (Co), which are among the most toxic of heavy metals, are used in metallurgy for the production of iron-based alloys. In addition, both the metals are commonly used in the chemistry and food industries as catalysts, in the production of paint and battery and in the electroplate industry (Gikas, 2008).

The genotoxic characterization of the soil can provide information about polluted areas because most pollutants, especially heavy metals, eventually accumulate in the soil. Plant roots are the primary contact points of pollutants in the soil. Plants might overcome environmental stress by developing some effective and specific physiological and biochemical mechanisms to a certain extent. Exposure to toxic heavy metal ions, however, causes some cellular stress responses and damages in some cellular components such as membrane, protein and DNA (Briat and Lebrun, 1999; Liu et al., 2005).

Being good indicators for cytogenetic and mutagenic effects, higher plants provide a useful genetic system for monitoring environmental pollutants. Thus, the mutagenic effects of some chemicals were investigated using plant systems such as Allium cepa, Arabidopsis thaliana, Hordeum vulgare, Glycine max, Tradescantia sp, Vicia faba, Zea mays and Phaseolus vulgaris. Using these plants, chromosome aberrations and mutations, such as chlorophyll spot mutation and specific locus mutation, which result from heavy metals, were investigated. Most of the studies were based on the analyses of genetic markers in which mutations could be observed in phenotype. However, in most cases, molecular applications using plant systems are limited due to the complexity of plant genome, ploidy level, difficulties in isolation of easily scorable phenotypes, and so on. Improvements in molecular marker technology provide new tools for detecting genetic changes analyzing DNA sequence and structure. Notably, polymerase chain reaction (PCR)-based molecular markers are useful for the DNA analysis of complex genomes. Using PCR reaction, nearly all mutation events, such as point mutation, small insertion and deletion, rearrangement, and so on, can be observed (Cesniene et al., 2010; Conte et al., 1998). In some studies, comet assay, micronucleus assay and chromosome aberrations were used in order to assess the genotoxic effects of metals on plants. Because of the sensitivity and short response period, evaluation of genotoxic effects of chemicals directly on DNA is advantageous (Cenkci et al., 2009; Labra et al., 2003; Liu et al., 2005). Recently, improvements in molecular biology paved the way for developing a lot of selective and sensitive methods for DNA analysis in genotoxicology. Random amplification of polymorphic DNA (RAPD) is a PCR-based technique that amplifies random DNA fragments of genomic DNA using short single primer having random nucleotide sequence under low-annealing conditions. It is commonly used in species classification, genetic mapping, phylogeny, and so on. In addition, as a keystone of original biomarker methods, RAPD is applied to detect various DNA damages and mutations induced by genotoxic factors, such as rearrangement, point mutation, small insertion and deletion of DNA and ploidy changes, in genomic DNA. After PCR optimization and selection of suitable primers, reproducible DNA profiles in terms of band number, yield amount and clearness were produced in a range of plants, aquatic invertebrates and bacteria species. RAPD were used successfully to detect DNA damages induced by genotoxins. After optimization, this method provides a number of advantages in detecting DNA damages. It is possible to analyze a large number of samples quickly by RAPD. As it uses random primers, it does not need specific details of DNA damages and genome sequence information of organisms. In addition, radioactive or enzymatic degradation of PCR products are not required for the analysis (Atienzar et al., 2000, 2002; Liu et al., 2009; Rancelis et al., 2006; Swaileh et al., 2008).

The main objective of this study was to detect the genetic instability in DNA alterations in Z. mays exposed to Ni and Co at various concentrations using RAPD technique and SDS-PAGE analysis. Our results provide important insights into DNA damage induced by toxic chemicals and how to identify the genotoxic effects.

sec.title: Plant growth and treatment conditions
sec.p: Z. mays L. seeds were obtained from the Department of Field Crops, Faculty of Agriculture, Ataturk University (Turkey). Z. mays seeds of equal size were chosen and surface sterilized with 2.5%/w/v of NaOCl for 3 min. After this treatment, the seeds were rinsed with water for four times and dried using sterile filter paper. The seeds were soaked in sterile distilled water for 1 h and then 15 seeds were germinated in 15-cm diameter petri dishes on four layers of sterile Whatman number 1 filter paper. Solution containing 0 (control), 5 mM, 10 mM, 20 mM and 40 mM of Co(NO3)2 (6H2O) and 5 mM, 10 mM, 20 mM and 40 mM of NiCl2 (6H2O) were added to each plate (Tables 1 and 2). The dishes were allowed to germinate in dark at 25°C.

Molecular sizes (bp) of appeared/disappeared bands in randomly amplified polymorphic DNA profiles of Ni-treated Zea mays seedlings.

sec.title: Determination of total protein content
sec.p: Quantitative estimation of total protein in the ground tissue of roots, shoot and leaves systems of Z. mays seedling were estimated according to Lowry et al. (1951). Each experiment was performed at least three times. Analysis of variance (ANOVA) was conducted using a one-way ANOVA test using SPSS 12.0 for Microsoft Windows, and means were compared by Duncan’s multiple range tests at the 0.001 level of confidence.

sec.title: Genomic DNA extraction and RAPDs procedures
sec.p: Genomic DNA was extracted from powdered plant materials using a modified method described by Li and Quiros (2001). Z. mays control groups were screened for RAPD variation using standard 10-base primers supplied by Operon. Reaction mixture (30 μl) was prepared as follows: 10× buffer 3.0 μl, dNTPs (10 mM) 1.2 μl, magnesium chloride (25 mM) 1.2 μl, primer (5 mM) 2.0 μl, Taq polymerase (5 units) 0.4 μl, water 19.2 μl and sample DNA 3.0 μl (100 ng/μl).
A total of 40 oligonucleotide primers were screened; and among them, 16 primers were selected and used for the further studies.

Sequences (5′ → 3′) from primer 1–16 utilized are CAGCACCCAC (OPA-13), CACTCTCCTC (OPH-17), TGCCGAGCTG (OPA-2), CAGGCCCTTC (OPA-1), GGTCCCTGAC (OPA-6), ACCAGGTTGG (OPH-14), GAATCGGCCA (OPH-18), GTGGCATCTC (OPY-1), AAGGCTCACC (OPY-6), AGGCAGAGCA (OPY-8), AGTCGCCCTT (OPY-15), GGGCCAATGT (OPY-16), CTCAGTGTCC (OPW-1), GTCCACACGG (OPB-8), CTGGACGTCA (OPW-7), GGCGGATAAG (OPW-5), respectively.

The thermal cycler was programmed as 2 min for initial denaturation at 95°C; 2 cycles of 30 s at 95°C, 1 min annealing at 37°C, 2 min extension at 72°C; 2 cycles of 30 s at 95°C, 1 min at 35°C, 2 min at 72°C; 41 cycles of 30 s at 94°C, 1 min at 35°C, 2 min at 72°C; followed by a final 5-min extension at 72°C then brought down to 4°C.

sec.title: Electrophoresis
sec.p: The PCR products (27 μl) were mixed with 6× gel loading buffer (3 μl) and loaded onto an agarose (1.5% w/v) gel electrophoresis in 0.5× Tris-Borate-EDTA (TBE) buffer at 70 V for 150 min. Amplification products separated by gel were stained in ethidium bromide solution (2 μl Etbr/100 ml 1× TBE buffer) for 40 min. The amplified DNA products were detected using the Bio Doc Image Analysis System with Uvi-soft analysis package (Cambridge Electronic Design Ltd, Cambridge, UK). RAPD patterns were evaluated using computer software Total Lab TL120.
Genomic template stability (GTS, %) was calculated using the following equation GTS=1−an×100

where a is the average number of polymorphic bands detected in each treated sample and n the number of total bands in the control. Polymorphism in RAPD profiles included disappearance of a normal band and appearance of a new band in comparison with the control. The average was calculated for each experimental group exposed to different concentrations of Co or Ni. To compare the sensitivity of each parameter, changes in these values were calculated as a percentage of their control (set to 100%).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: In total, 40 oligonucleotide primers with 60%–70% GC content were used for analyzing the PCR products of fodder Z. mays genome and only 16 gave specific and stable results (Tables 1 and 2). Compared with the PCR products obtained from the control DNA, Ni or Co treatments resulted in apparent changes in RAPD patterns. These changes are characterized by variation in band intensity, loss of normal bands or appearance of new bands (Figures 1 and 2). In contrast to the control, RAPD profiles of Co-treated seedlings amplified with the primers OPH-17, OPA-2 and OPY-6 showed significant decrease in the band number, while amplification with the primer OPW-5 resulted in an increase in the band number, with increased concentration of Co. Molecular size of appeared bands ranged from 27 bp to 1273 bp and that of disappeared bands ranged from 58 bp to 1923 bp in RAPD profiles of Co-treated seedlings (Table 1). In Ni-treated seedlings, on the other hand, the band number increased with the amplification of the primers OPA-6, OPH-14 and OPB-8, while decreased with the amplification of the primers OPH-18, OPY-1, OPY-8, OPY-16 and OPW-7 in comparison with the control. Molecular size of appeared bands was 261–1021 bp while that of disappeared bands was 127–1128 bp in the amplifications with Ni-treated plants (Table 2). Value of polymorphism increased with increasing concentration of Co or Ni treatments.

caption.p: Randomly amplified polymorphic DNA profiles of Co-exposed and nonexposed Zea mays seedlings with primers of (a) OPH-18 and OPY-6 as well as (b) OPW-7 and OPW-5.
Randomly amplified polymorphic DNA profiles of Ni-exposed and nonexposed Zea mays seedlings with primers of (a) OPA-13 and OPH-17 as well as (b) OPA-6 and OPH-14.

sec.p: GTS was used for comparing the changes in RAPD profiles. GTS values tended to decrease with increasing concentration of Co or Ni treatments. In Co treatments, GTS value did not change for all the concentrations (5 mM, 10 mM, 20 mM and 40 mM) in the amplification with the primer OPH-18, and the average values obtained from the amplifications with all the primers were 62.1%, 55.7%, 52.5% and 46.1% (Table 3). In Ni treatments, GTS value was stable for all the concentrations in amplifications with the primers OPA-2, OPA-1, OPA-6, OPH-14, OPH-18, OPY-6, OPY-16 and OPW-7 (Table 4).

caption.p: Changes in genomic template stability values of all primers in Zea mays seedling exposed to different Co concentrations.
Changes in genomic template stability values of all primers in Zea mays seedling exposed to different Ni concentrations.

sec.p: The proteins obtained from the seedlings of maize treated with different concentrations of Co/Ni were isolated and investigated by sodium dodecyl sulfate–polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE). Total protein level was decreased significantly by Co treatment, while it was increased by Ni treatment (Figures 3 and 4).

Comparison of total soluble protein levels in maize seedlings exposed to different concentrations of Ni.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In the present study, genotoxic effects of Ni and Co elements on Z. mays were examined using RAPD technique. Besides, protein profiles of metal-treated plants were evaluated by SDS-PAGE.

Although Ni is one of the essential elements, it is required by plants in highly low doses. Seeds having small amounts of Ni can sustain normal plant growth and development (Küpper et al., 2001). However, excessive Ni treatments have detrimental effects on organisms. Ni ions can produce hydroxyl radicals and reactive oxygen species in cells. Free radicals produced by Ni ions can cause point mutations and strand breakages directly or indirectly interfering with DNA repair system. It is also known that Ni ions change cytosine methylation patterns in the cell causing hypo- or hyper-methylation of DNA. Hypomethylation can increase the susceptibility of the chromosomes to breakages. On the other hand, hypermethylation can cause chromosomal instability with its harmful effects in the cell (Kovalchuk et al., 2001).

Ni ions show high affinity for proteins in comparison with DNA. Therefore, it can be stated that the genotoxicity caused by Ni ions is dependent on the interactions of Ni ions with chromatin proteins. These interactions may lead to the deleterious effects on heterochromatic chromosome regions which have compact protein-DNA structure. It was shown that Ni compounds form DNA-protein cross-links (Costa et al., 1994). Lee et al. (1998) also indicated that Ni ions have interactions with proteins and other intracellular molecules and likely have a similar effect on gene expression. In addition, Ni ions prevent proteins from binding to DNA. Blinda et al. (1997) showed increased levels of messenger RNA in barley seedlings exposed to Ni. In a micronucleus assay on Tradescantia sp. and Vicia sp., Knasmüller et al. (1998) reported that Ni induces mutagenicity stemming from genotoxicity. Moreover, cytogenetic and gene mutation assays on mammalian cells as well as chromosome aberration assays on rodent cells produced positive results in terms of genotoxicity. Ni-induced mutations are caused due to single-strand DNA breaks and DNA-protein cross-links (Knasmüller et al., 1998; Sen et al., 1987).

Being one of the essential microelements, Co is a component of some enzymes and coenzymes. It affects plant growth and metabolism in various degrees, depending on its concentration (Tewari et al., 2002). When organisms are exposed to excessive concentrations of Co, it induces DNA damage, DNA-protein cross-links and sister chromatid exchange directly. In addition, Co interferes with DNA repair system (Leonard et al., 1998). In a study conducted on V. faba plants, in order to investigate the effect of Co treatment on polymorphism, Co-exposed seeds of some Fabaceae plants showed individual polymorphism (Rancelis et al., 2006).

DNA fingerprinting presents useful biomarkers for ecotoxicology. Band alterations observed in DNA fingerprinting analyses reflect a range of DNA changes from point mutations to complex chromosomal rearrangements (Atienzar et al., 2000; Liu et al., 2005). Once optimized, RAPD is a reliable, sensitive and reproducible biomarker in detecting DNA damage and mutations. Therefore, it can be used widely in genotoxicity and carcinogenesis (Atienzar and Jha, 2006; Cenkci et al., 2010). Despite the criticism of RAPD assay, due to the lack of reproducibility, after a careful optimization of the PCR parameters, RAPD, which offers advantages in terms of amplified bands, clearness of produced yield and profiles, can be applied to a range of organisms from bacteria and plants to vertebrate and invertebrate animals (Atienzar and Jha, 2004). In an unrelated study, appearance and disappearance of bands were observed in RAPD profiles of the rats exposed to benzo(a)pyrene by comparison with the control patterns (Savva, 1996). Similar results were also reported by Atienzar et al. (2000) in a study conducted on an algae species. Atienzar et al. (2000) applied RAPD technique successfully to detect UV-induced DNA damage in Palmaria palmate, a marine macroalgae, and showed that this technique is a reliable and reproducible assay for genotoxicity.

Loss of normal PCR products may be caused by genotoxin-induced DNA damage (e.g. single and double strand breaks, modified bases, oxidized bases and DNA-protein cross-links), point mutations and complex chromosomal rearrangements (Atienzar et al., 1999, 2000; Cenkci et al., 2010). New PCR products may result from mutations in some oligonucleotide priming sites, changes due to large deletions and homolog recombination (Atienzar et al., 1999; Cenkci et al., 2010). Cenkci et al. (2010) indicated that the total numbers of appeared and disappeared bands in RAPD profiles of lead-exposed Brassica rapa seedlings are almost the same. Moreover, the disappeared bands show a tendency of high molecular weights (>1000 bp), while new bands have low molecular weights (<1000 bp). Similar results were also observed in the RAPD profiles of barley (H. vulgare) and rice (Oryza sativa) exposed to Cd (Cenkci et al., 2010; Liu et al., 2005, 2007).

It is considered that the alterations in RAPD profiles due to genotoxic agents reflect the changes in GTS. Being a way of qualitative measurement of genotoxic effects, GTS is related to the level of DNA damage and the efficacy of DNA repair and replication (Atienzar et al., 1999, 2000; Cenkci et al., 2010; Liu et al., 2005). Our findings about Ni- or Co-exposed Z. mays plants reveal decreased GTS with increased Ni or Co concentrations. For Ni treatment, in RAPD patterns of the primers OPA-1, OPA-2, OPA-6, OPH-14, OPH-18, OPY-6, OPY-16 and OPW-7, the GTS remained constant with a decreased value in comparison with the control. However, such constancy was observed only for the primer OPH-18 in Co treatment. Other primers showed decreased genetic template stability values with increased Co concentration. For the Co concentrations of 5 mM, 10 mM and 20 mM, it was also unexpected that RAPD patterns of the primer OPW-7 have the same GTS with the control. These genomic instabilities in RAPD patterns reflect DNA damages induced by genotoxins, that is, Ni or Co treatment. These changes are consistent with SDS-PAGE analysis of protein profiles.

In conclusion, as a sensitive and reliable assay, RAPD can be used to detect DNA damages induced by heavy metals such as Ni and Co. By this study, it is demonstrated that Z. mays can be used as a bioindicator of genotoxins.
